> Thomas Obst wrote:
>
> >Why then does JUnit display the number of test cases? If it is
> interesting to know how
> >many test cases the system has passed, then it is also
> interesting to know how many
> >asserts have made it. This is especially true if a test case is
> something like testMethod(),
> >where the individual asserts verify that various values of the
> parameters to method()
> >work (max, min, null, normal, etc). Sure these could all be
> individual test cases, but then
> >it becomes difficult to see whether I really have exhaustively
> tested my method. Code
> >coverage is not the solution. That only tells me whether what I
> have written, opposed to
> >what I should have written, works.
> >
> Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
> Ok imagine JUnit implements the counting of assertions.  You run your
> tests and get "90 tests, 405 assertions".  That's great, but what does
> this number "405" tells you?  And what is that better than "90 tests,
> 404 assertions" and worst than "90 tests, 406 assertions"?  Does this
> magic number "405" tell you that the "individual asserts verify that
> various values of the parameters to method() work (max, min, null,
> normal, etc)".  Do you expect a certain ration #assertions/#tests?
>
> How does this magic "405" tells you that you have tested what you
> _should have_ written?  I you don't know what you should have written, I
> doubt that a simple number could tell you that...
>

"90 tests, 405 assertions" doesn't tell me much, however seeing something
like "90 tests, 0 assertions" should raise a red flag in anyone's eyes. This
sort of thing does happen and needs to be highlighted.
